title: 1949 newsletter font
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017074833im_/http:/myfonts-wtf.s3.amazonaws.com/c8/c8b7d3a54a6ef780a3e244beaed81766.41913.png)  
This is from a December 1949 newsletter printed in the United States, probably in Michigan. For what it’s worth, it looks similar to (but not the same as) [Decora](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017074833/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bogusky2/decora/) to me.
author: nwhetsell

comments.content: Wow: what fun. This isn't a foundry type that I'm familiar with. Given the regularity of the repeating characters, it's probably not hand-lettered, but rather the work of some clip-art service...

Looks similar to some Sol Hess designs.  
Here's a similar one: [Twentieth Century Poster](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017074833/http:/www.linotype.com/174979/twentieth-century-poster-mt-product.html).  
Will see if I can find a closer match.  
Don

Here’s an image showing the font in context, in case the art is connected to the font somehow.  
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017074833im_/https:/dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/21723817/SigmanDecember1949Cover.png)

Let's not forget Nick's version of Twentieth Century Poster [Renard Moderne NF](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017074833/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/renard-moderne-nf/l).  
I wonder if the 1949 newsletter heading is an early photo-composition effort. I can't find anything more about it.  
Don
